Uses of Class
fullsoft.RegModel.RegModel

    • Uses of RegModel in fullsoft.RegModel

      Methods in fullsoft.RegModel that return RegModel 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      RegModel RegModel.acceptWordChars(fullsoft.RegModel.RegModelEqualChars acceptChar) 
      RegModel RegModel.any()
      It is select all rest characters to the begin of string if direction is right to the left.
      RegModel RegModel.any(int minTimes)

      Example:
         Regex6 r = new Regex6("abc");
         r.any().getString(); => "abc"
      RegModel RegModel.any(int minTimes, int maxTimes) 
      RegModel RegModel.any1() 
      RegModel RegModel.betweenCode(char first, char last) 
      RegModel RegModel.betweenCode(int minTimes, char first, char last) 
      RegModel RegModel.betweenCode(int minTimes, int maxTimes, char first, char last) 
      RegModel RegModel.betweenCode1(char first, char last) 
      RegModel RegModel.can$()
      It is ok, if next model selector does not match anything.
      RegModel RegModel.char1(char oneChar)
      Select next one character
      Example:
      private void char1() {
         String bigString = "Woooommmen.";
         RegModel regModel = new RegModel(bigString);
         regModel.char1('W'); //=> ok, selected model is 'W'
         regModel.chars(1,2,"o"); //=> ok, selected model is 'oo'
         regModel.chars(1,"moe"); //=> ok, selected model is 'oommme'
      }
      RegModel RegModel.char1(java.lang.String chars) 
      RegModel RegModel.chars(int minTimes, int maxTimes, java.lang.String chars)

      Example:
         String bigString = "Woooommmen.";
         RegModel regModel = new RegModel(bigString);
         regModel.chars("moW"); //=> ok, marked CharSequence is "Woooommm";
         regModel.fromStart$();
         regModel.chars( 0, -> minimal consecutive characters, 0 - means it is ok if is not
              3, -> maximal consecutive characters
              "33"); //=> ok, marked CharSequence is ""
         regModel.chars( 1, -> minimal consecutive characters, 1 - means at least one character
              3, -> maximal consecutive characters
              "moW"); //=> ok, marked CharSequence is 'Woooommm'
      RegModel RegModel.chars(int minTimes, java.lang.String chars) 
      RegModel RegModel.chars(java.lang.String chars) 
      RegModel RegModel.digits()
      Select all next characters which are digits 0..9
         String bigString = "Height 10 meters";
         RegModel regModel = new RegModel(bigString);
         regModel.fromStart$();
         regModel.not$().digits(); //=> ok, marked CharSequence is 'Height '
         regModel.digits(); //=> ok, marked CharSequence model is '10'
      RegModel RegModel.digits(int minTimes) 
      RegModel RegModel.digits(int minTimes, int maxTimes) 
      RegModel RegModel.digits1() 
      RegModel RegModel.else$()
      Modifier used in case of a mismatch (model after if$ modifier returns false boolean) to give access for further manipulation with the next model.
      RegModel RegModel.endIf$() 
      RegModel RegModel.endOf() 
      RegModel RegModel.firstOf() 
      RegModel RegModel.firstOf(java.util.Collection<java.lang.String> arr) 
      RegModel RegModel.firstOf(java.util.Collection<java.lang.String> arr, int start, int end) 
      RegModel RegModel.firstOf(int start, int end, java.lang.String... arr) 
      RegModel RegModel.firstOf(java.lang.String... arr) 
      RegModel RegModel.fromEnd$()
      Matches the ending of the input.
      RegModel RegModel.fromStart$()
      Move the cursor to the start of string, next model selector have to start from begin of string.
      RegModel RegModel.has(int minTimes, int maxTimes, java.lang.String subStr) 
      RegModel RegModel.has(int minTimes, java.lang.String subStr) 
      RegModel RegModel.has(java.lang.String subStr) 
      RegModel RegModel.if$()
      RegModel modifier that allows further manipulation and search of the CharSequence in the RegModel, based on the output of the model used after it (whether there is a match or a mismatch).
      RegModel RegModel.letter() 
      RegModel RegModel.letter(int minTimes) 
      RegModel RegModel.letter(int minTimes, int maxTimes) 
      RegModel RegModel.not$()
      A modifier that denies the next model.
      RegModel RegModel.number() 
      RegModel RegModel.number(int minTimes) 
      RegModel RegModel.number(int minTimes, int maxTimes) 
      RegModel RegModel.number1() 
      RegModel RegModel.reset(java.lang.CharSequence s) 
      RegModel RegModel.seek(java.util.function.Consumer<RegModel> models)

      Example:
        String bigString = "height is 10 meters, but height is not too big.";
        RegModel regModel = new RegModel(bigString);
        regModel.seek(0,2,(r)->{
         regModel.any().has("height").wspace().word();
        });
        System.out.println( regModel.ok() );
        
        int max = 2, min = 0; int count = 0;
        while( count<max && regModel.any().has("height").wspace().word().ok() ) {
         count++;
        }
        if(count<min) regModel.err();
        if(regModel.err() && count==0 && min==0) regModel.setOK();
        
        System.out.println( regModel.ok() );
        }
      Note:
      This method can be modified with modifiers such as can$(), not$(), etc.
      RegModel RegModel.seek(int minTimes, java.util.function.Consumer<RegModel> models) 
      RegModel RegModel.seek(int minTimes, int maxTimes, java.util.function.Consumer<RegModel> models)

      Note:
      Check out the example in the seek() method description.
      RegModel RegModel.seek1(java.util.function.Consumer<RegModel> models)

      Note:
      Check out the example in the seek() method description.
      RegModel RegModel.since()

      Marks the next char after the current marked CharSequence as a starting point.
      RegModel RegModel.then$()
      Modifier used in case of a match (model after if$ modifier returns true boolean) to give access for further manipulation with the next model.
      RegModel RegModel.toLeft$()
      Change direction to search models from right to the left.
      RegModel RegModel.toRight$()
      Change direction to search for models from left to right.
      RegModel RegModel.wordEnd$()
      Regex object modifier - matches the end of the input.
      RegModel RegModel.wordStart$()
      Regex object modifier - matches the beginning of the input.
      RegModel RegModel.wspace()

      Note: Check out the example in wspace1() description.
      RegModel RegModel.wspace(int minTimes)

      Note: Check out the example in wspace1() description.
      RegModel RegModel.wspace(int minTimes, int maxTimes)

      Note: Check out the example in wspace1() description.
      RegModel RegModel.wspace1()

      Example:
      String bigString = "This is CharSequence.";
      RegModel regModel = new RegModel(bigString);
      regModel.letter(); -> marked CharSequence (0-4) "This"
      regModel.wspace(); -> marked CharSequence (4-5) " "
      regModel.any(); -> marked CharSequence (5-21) "is CharSequence."
      regModel.wspace1(); marked CharSequence (5-8)"is " System.out.println(regModel.ok());
      Method parameters in fullsoft.RegModel with type arguments of type RegModel 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      void RegModel.onError(java.util.function.Consumer<RegModel> errConsumer) 
      void RegModel.onSyntaxError(java.util.function.BiConsumer<RegModel,java.lang.String> errConsumer) 
      RegModel RegModel.seek(java.util.function.Consumer<RegModel> models)

      Example:
        String bigString = "height is 10 meters, but height is not too big.";
        RegModel regModel = new RegModel(bigString);
        regModel.seek(0,2,(r)->{
         regModel.any().has("height").wspace().word();
        });
        System.out.println( regModel.ok() );
        
        int max = 2, min = 0; int count = 0;
        while( count<max && regModel.any().has("height").wspace().word().ok() ) {
         count++;
        }
        if(count<min) regModel.err();
        if(regModel.err() && count==0 && min==0) regModel.setOK();
        
        System.out.println( regModel.ok() );
        }
      Note:
      This method can be modified with modifiers such as can$(), not$(), etc.
